learning_outcomes.description: Better appreciate fundamental issues in metaphysics and epistemology
Analyse problems and communicate with improved precision and clarity
Think critically, systemically, independently and creatively in analysing complex problems
Compare and assess opposing philosophical theses and assumptions
Better understand human experience and its relationship to the world

assessments.task_description: You will be required to summarize and reflect on the positions and arguments covered in the theory of knowledge part of the course (weeks 2-6). This will be done in writing during the scheduled tutorial time for week 7.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>20% 2 points for preparation and participation in each tutorial </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Marks credited for weekly contributions to a community of philosophical inquiry in 10 tutorials. Tutorials run on weeks 2-13 excluding week 10.

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.weighting: <dd>45% 45 points for writing an essay (1800 words +/-10%) </dd>
assessments.task_description:
-Write 1800 words (+/-10%) on one topic from the reality part of the course. Topics will be suggested but you are also allowed to research and write on a question that particularly interests you and that you have discussed with the lecturer. See the assignment sheet on blackboard.


-Whilst AI use is not prohibited, we strongly recommend that it not be used to write essays as the essay task will require students to critically engage in specific contexts for which AI provides only limited support and guidance. In summary, Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.


-A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria. 


-Meticulously cite your sources, including by citing specific page numbers. If you are citing lecture material, cite specific lectures and slides.
